review.title: Finding Academic Experts on a MultiSensor Approach using Shannon's Entropy
review.abstract: Expert finding is an information retrieval task concerned with the search for the most knowledgeable people, in some topic, with basis on documents describing peoples activities. The task involves taking a user query as input and returning a list of people sorted by their level of expertise regarding the user query. This paper introduces a novel approach for combining multiple estimators of expertise based on a multisensor data fusion framework together with the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence and Shannon's entropy. More specifically, we defined three sensors which detect heterogeneous information derived from the textual contents, from the graph structure of the citation patterns for the community of experts, and from profile information about the academic experts. Given the evidences collected, each sensor may define different candidates as experts and consequently do not agree in a final ranking decision. To deal with these conflicts, we applied the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence combined with Shannon's Entropy formula to fuse this information and come up with a more accurate and reliable final ranking list. Experiments made over two datasets of academic publications from the Computer Science domain attest for the adequacy of the proposed approach over the traditional state of the art approaches. We also made experiments against representative supervised state of the art algorithms. Results revealed that the proposed method achieved a similar performance when compared to these supervised techniques, confirming the capabilities of the proposed framework.

sections.heading: 1.2 Outline
sections.text: The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents the main concepts and related work in the literature; Section 3 explains the multi-sensor framework proposed in this paper, as well as all the events that each sensor can detect, and the data fusion techniques used merge all the events that are perceived by each sensor; Section 4 formalizes the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence; Section 5 describes the Shannon entropy formula developed for this work; Section 6 presents the data sets used in our experiments, as well as the evaluation metrics used; Section 7 presents the results of the experiments and a brief discussion; and finally, Section 8 presents the main conclusions of this work.

sections.heading: 3 A MultiSensor Approach for Expert Finding
sections.text: The multi-sensor approach proposed in this paper includes three different sensors: a text sensor, a profile sensor and a citation sensor. The text sensor takes into account textual similarities between the content of the documents associated with a candidate and the query topics in order to make expert assessments. If there is text evidence for a candidate in which the query topics occur frequently, then it is likely that this candidate is an expert in the topic expressed by the query. The profile sensor takes into account the amount of publications a candidate has made during his or her career. Highly productive candidates are more likely to be considered experts. Finally, the citation sensor takes into account the impact of a candidate in the scientific community and also relies on linkage structures, such as citation graphics, to determine the candidate's knowledge. Candidates with high citation patterns are accepted as experts.The multi-sensor approach proposed in this paper consists of two different fusion processes: (one), each of which is covered by a second sensor event, each of which a different sensor system is associated with a specific event.

sections.heading: 3.2 The MultiSensor Fusion Process
sections.text: The multi-sensor fusion process is responsible for calculating all the mass functions required by the Dempster Shafer Framework, and for calculating the amount of information each sensor contributes to the system through Shannon's entropy formula. This process is illustrated in Figure 4.After the events captured by a number of candidates have been detected and merged, each sensor has a ranking in which the candidates it assumed to be experts come out on top. However, most of the leading experts in these lists disagree, leading to a conflict that needs to be addressed in order to reach a final decision. The Dempster Shafer is then used to calculate the mass functions of each sensor m (a).

sections.heading: 3.3 Example
sections.text: When a user submits a query with a topic of interest, each sensor is responsible for recognizing specific events related to the relationship between a candidate and the query. To give a clear example of how the proposed system works, we assume that a user does not want to know the top experts in information retrieval. The first step of our system is to retrieve all authors who have the query topics in their publications or abstracts. To simplify matters, we assume that the system has only found three authors with such terms: Autor1, Autor2 and Autor3.Each author has a set of documents that are related to them. Each sensor is responsible for recognizing different types of information in these documents. The text sensor recognizes various events such as term frequency, inverse document frequency, BM25, etc. The profile sensor on the other hand is responsible for recognizing the entire publication record of the candidate. And the co-citation sensor must detect events such as the number of work of the author, the number of quotes, the number of candidates, etc.

sections.heading: 4 The Dempster-Shafer Theory of Evidence
sections.text: The Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence provides a way of associating uncertainties with sets of hypotheses when the individual hypotheses are imprecise or unknown (Shocken and Humme, 1993). All possible mutually exclusive hypotheses are contained within the framework of distinguishing between the possible combinations of these authors, that is, our hypotheses become if either an author is an expert or not.

sections.heading: 5 Shannon’s Entropy
sections.text: In information theory, entropy is defined as a measure of the uncertainty of a random variable. Let S be a discrete random variable representing a sensor. Let's suppose that E is the totality of all events {e1, e2,..., e | E |} that can be detected by sensor S. Let's assume that E is the totality of all events {a1, a2,..., a | A}. Let relevant event (e, a) be a function that determines whether the event e is relevant to the author of a value determined by the sensor. sections.heading: 7 Experimental Results
sections.text: In this section, we present the results of the experiments carried out in this paper, more specifically: 1. In Section 7.1, we compared our multi-sensor approach with a general aggregation framework using only the proximity dataset; 2. In Section 7.2, we determined the effects of each sensor of our multi-sensor approach using the proximity dataset; and experiments showed that the combination of the text similarity sensor with the citation sensor produced the best results in this dataset; and 2. In Section 7.2, we determined the impact of each sensor of our multi-sensor approach using the proximity dataset; and 3. In Section 7.3, we repeated the experiments of our multi-sensor approach with an enriched version of the BLP datasets.

sections.heading: 7.1 Comparison of the MultiSesnor approach Against a General Rank Aggregation Approach using the Proximity Dataset
sections.text: The main hypothesis that motivates this experiment is to test whether our multi-sensor approach, in combination with the Dempster Shafer Evidence Theory, produces better results than a standard ranking approach. To confirm this hypothesis, we experimented our multi-sensor approach with various data fusion techniques and compared it to the ranking framework using the same fusion algorithms. Table 13 presents the results obtained for the three sensors proposed, namely the text similarity sensor, the profile information sensor, and the cite sensor. The results in Table 13 show that our multi-sensor approach, using the Dempster Shafer framework, exceeded the general ranking approach. If two sensors do not match, it is difficult to make a final decision whether a candidate is an expert or not. In these situations, a standard ranking approach simply ignores the conflict and applies a data fusion technology to combine the values of the two sensors.

sections.heading: 7.2 Determining the Impact of the Different Sensors in the MultiSensor Approach
sections.text: The data gathered in the previous experiment showed that the proposed multi-sensor approach in combination with the Condorcet Fusion algorithm achieved the best results by combining three sensors: the text similarity sensor, the profile information sensor and the citation sensor. In this experiment, we are interested in determining the impact of the different sensors in our multi-sensor approach. To confirm this, we tested our multi-sensor approach separately along with (i) the text similarity and the profile sensors, (ii) the text similarity and the citation sensors, and (iii) the profile and the citation sensors. Table 14 shows that the best results were obtained when the text similarity sensor cooperates with the citation sensor. This means that the presence of the query topics in the author's document, together with information on the author's impact in the scientific community, plays an important role.

sections.heading: 7.3 Performance of the MultiSensor Approach in the Enriched DBLP Dataset
sections.text: In this experiment, we are looking at the performance of our multi-sensor approach in enriched datasets, more precisely in the enriched version of the DBLP dataset. Results are presented in Table 15.Table 15 that our multi-sensor approach, together with the Condorcet Fusion algorithm, delivered the best performance, an improvement of more than 46% over the standard rank aggregation approach using the same fusion algorithm. Although our multi-sensor fusion approach using the Dempster shafer outperformed all other standard rank aggregation methods, we cannot conclude that our approach is better as no statistical significance was found. In a separate experiment, we also tried to determine which combinations of sensors provided the best results for this dataset. Table 16 shows the statistical results obtained. In this experiment, the best results were obtained when the similarity of the text or the specific results with the presence of the author are so strong in the connection.

sections.heading: 7.4 Comparison with State of the Art
sections.text: In this experiment, we looked at the state-of-the-art effects of our multi-sensor approach. Table 17 presents the results of the basic models proposed by K. Balog (Balog et al., 2006), namely the candidate model 1 and the document-based model 2. To make the comparison fair, we used the code provided by K. Balog at http: / / code.google.com / p / ea. Experiments showed that Model 1 and Model 2 performed similarly in such a data set, but performed less well compared to the multisensor approach. In Model 1, when an author publishes an essay that contains a set of words that match the topics in question, this author scores very highly in this model. Moreover, since we are dealing with very large data sets, there are many authors in such a situation, and as a result, the best-placed authors are dominated by non-experts, while the real experts are ranked lower in the rankings, because we only see the respective titles and some of the summaries in the respective summaries.

sections.heading: 7.5 Comparison with State of the Art Supervised Approaches
sections.text: This year, it will be able to leave the country and move into a new world.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: We have a multi-sensor approach using the Dempster Shafer Theory of Uncertainty. To extract different sources of knowledge from these documents, we have defined three sensors: a text similarity sensor, a profile sensor, and a number sensor. The text sensor collects events that are more likely to be considered experts, and the number sensor uses the authority of the candidates and the documents assigned to a candidate. The profile sensor measures the total number of candidates over the course of their career.

referenceMentions.context: These techniques are based on several computer science domains such as artificial intelligence, pattern recognition and statistical estimation (Varshney, 1997).

Many previous works of the literature addressed this issue through the usage of the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence in order to provide a better reasoning process (Wu et al., 2002; Li et al., 2008).

In information retrieval systems, for instance, the Dempster-Shafer theory can be used to effectively quantify the relevance between documents and queries (Lalmas and Moutogianni, 2000; Lalmas and Ruthven, 1998).
The events detected by each sensor are based on the preliminary research in (Moreira et al., 2011).

Later, (Balog et al., 2009) and (Petkova and Croft, 2007) have introduced the idea of dependency between candidates and query topics by including a surrounding window to weight the strength of the associations between candidates and query topics.
Later, (Balog et al., 2009) explored the usage of positional information and formalized a document representation which includes a window surrounding the candidate’s name.
(Deng et al., 2011) proposed a query sensitive AuthorRank model.

(Moreira et al., 2011; Moreira, 2011) have also explored different learning to rank algorithms to find academic experts, where they defined a whole set of features based on textual similarities, on the author’s profile information and based on the author’s citation patterns.

(Moreira et al., 2011; Moreira, 2011) have also explored different learning to rank algorithms to find academic experts, where they defined a whole set of features based on textual similarities, on the author’s profile information and based on the author’s citation patterns.
For instance, (Li et al., 2008) used a set of artificial neural networks to identify the degree of damage of a bridge.
(Riker, 1988) suggested a classification to distinguish the different existing data fusion algorithms into two categories, namely the positional methods and the majoritarian algorithms.
Later, (Fox and Shaw, 1994) have also proposed the score aggregation methods.
Examples of such methods are CombSUM, CombMNZ and CombANZ, all proposed by (Fox and Shaw, 1994).
The events detected by each sensor are similar to the features proposed in the preliminary research work (Moreira et al., 2011) and therefore will not be detailed.

metadata.abstractText: Expert finding is an information retrieval task concerned with the search for the most knowledgeable people, in some topic, with basis on documents describing peoples activities. The task involves taking a user query as input and returning a list of people sorted by their level of expertise regarding the user query. This paper introduces a novel approach for combining multiple estimators of expertise based on a multisensor data fusion framework together with the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence and Shannon’s entropy. More specifically, we defined three sensors which detect heterogeneous information derived from the textual contents, from the graph structure of the citation patterns for the community of experts, and from profile information about the academic experts. Given the evidences collected, each sensor may define different candidates as experts and consequently do not agree in a final ranking decision. To deal with these conflicts, we applied the DempsterShafer theory of evidence combined with Shannon’s Entropy formula to fuse this information and come up with a more accurate and reliable final ranking list. Experiments made over two datasets of academic publications from the Computer Science domain attest for the adequacy of the proposed approach over the traditional state of the art approaches. We also made experiments against representative supervised state of the art algorithms. Results revealed that the proposed method achieved a similar performance when compared to these supervised techniques, confirming the capabilities of the proposed framework. This work was supported by national funds through FCT Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia, under project PEst-OE/EEI/LA0021/2011 and supported by national funds through FCT Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia, under project PTDC/EIA-CCO/119722/2010
